review_blob: This beer pours a clear reddish amber that ended up with just a small head. Hoppiness in the aroma, of course, also yeast and banana notes. Alcohol is also present in the smell, surprising for only 6.0abv. Decent bitterness to drink, maybe a tad watery and light. Caramel malts kick in but not strongly enough to overcome the bitter. Strong carbonation and bitter aftertaste. Pass on this one.

Well, rain and possibly snow are forecasted, dare I say threatened, for this weekend. It is the latter part of October in Maine and and such dreary portents do come early. On the upside, the winter brews are here! Sebago is seemingly on a quest to bottle all of their offerings and theyre a fine choice for my first winter sampling. Medium brown color with a hint of red. Smallish head that is insisting on staying for the journey. Malts and caramel greet the nose. The Black Patent and caramel malts take over the tasting and hang on to the tongue. Hops are nearly non-existant except for the bittering. This is a truly unique tasting beer begging to be experienced around a fire or during the midst of burning leaves. Itll be on my list for the last BBQ till spring.

Pours a innocuous ruddy brown color with a minor yet quite aggressive head. Aroma wells up and assaults the nose with tart fruity tones, strong with raisin and notes of brown sugar and malt. The taste begs to be savored with the raisin-malt combining beautifully with the brown sugar. The warming 20%abv oozes down your throat seemingly to dare any season changing coldbug to try and take hold. Just as I was tiring of DFHes heady IPAs and over-the-top sweet flavored brews they deliver a really unique tasting beer thats just meant to take a step back and bask in its enlightenment. After only a third of the way throught this 12oz messenger from the gods Im already nearing Nirvana!

Medium brownish-red looking beer that poured with an eager head which subsided quickly. Aroma was all about the tightly blended hops. I expected more of a typical spiced brew for this seasonal but it refreshingly drinks more like a light crisp English IPA. With an added prickly pine-cone mouth sensation. Hop lovers only need apply. Im definitely springing for another six!

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: I tried many of Magic Hats offerings and they dont suit my tastes.  Here we have a lightly fruit tasting beer with small brushing of hops.  Think Gerber applesauce mixed with a brown ale.  Love their marketing far better than their brews.

Damn near porter season. Love the richer and higher ABV offerings of the winter season but know the easy evenings sitting in the backyard looking over the freshly mowed grass are severely numbered. Sea Dog offers a damn fine porter with a powerful mouthfeel that leans a tad more heavily to the nuttier side of the toasted malt, mocha and coffee flavorings. Carbonation isnt in short supply and carries this rich brew through the tasting. You are left with a coffee flavored hop fizz. Nice zesty offering from Sea Dog.

Robust head with a brownish amber coloring. Lacing is covering far side of glass. Nutty malt aroma. Hops support malt flavor like laticework, reminiscent of English ales with a touch more bitter bite. A touch of spice and alcohol. Pleasant bitter caramel aftertaste. Will not hesitate to purchase again. Nice strong ale to go with the season.

This is a truly fine diversion until Bigfoot is once again available. Sweet crystalized fruit malt flavor that manages to come off lightly with a wheat bite. The alcohol is somewhat more noticable than some of the richer and deeper barleywines but you will plow through this offering like it was a pilsner. At $3.49 a 22oz bottle, Ill likely be cleaning out my local beverage supplier and suggest you do the same!
beer_name: Smuttynose Big Beer Series: Wheat Wine Ale

beer_brewer_name: Magic Hat Brewing Company (North American Breweries)
review_blob: This beer is an amalgamation of many of Magic Hats different brews. Considered a smoke beer but that isnt really evident. This medium brown beer poured with a sizable head that receeded quickly with much lacing. Earthy fruit aroma with a tiny touch of stale smoke. Malty with a tart fruit tang to taste without much hop to break things up. The higher than normal ABV may be cause to try this beer but it doesnt really lend any complexity.

This is the best fall seasonal Ive tried this year. Medium light orange and brown color that didnt respond with much of a head. Aroma is equal parts malt, hop and spice. The mouthfeel of this beer is fantastic, full and thick but without graininess or feeling syrupy. Taste is a perfect blend of all that is aforementioned with a perfect hop kick at the end and a splash of spice. No need for pumpkin pie, Ill have one of these for dessert!

Shiver me timbers, this is one damn fine Belgium brew! Pours a cloudy golden color with a willing head and lotsa fine lacing. Rich yeasty pineapple aroma. Creamy spice flavor with a gripping mouthfeel and lingering sweet marmalade and bread aftertaste with a hop tingle. Raise the Jolly Roger because Im off to plunder some more of this delicious booty!

Pours a deep amber color with large frothy head. Fresh hop and citrus aroma. Pine and citrus flavor with good bitterness. A tad too carbonated that keeps the beer light but lacking in body. Beer finishes quick and clean with bitter citrus peel aftertaste. Still an excellent brew considering this sample is a several months past due.
beer_name: Sea Dog (Old East) India Pale Ale

review_blob: This is a fun addition to the Becks lineup. Not as malty and true to form as Sam Adams Octoberfest but a good drink retaining the distinct light hop flavor Becks is known for. Worth picking up a six along with the rest of the fall seasonal brews.

Light brown and orange color. Poured with minimal head. Aroma of yeast and hop. Technically an ale this drank like a weak attempt at a dry Marzen. Had the malty flavor but tasted flat and dry. Mouthfeel was week and uninteresting. Take a pass on this one, too many other good Autumn brews to chose from.

Theres that sucking on a pinecone hop reference. The brewer musta been in the midst of a divorce when he hopped this one up. It nearly curls, or uncurls as the case may be, your nostril hairs to smell. This cloudy amber concoction stays lemonade tart the whole bomber way through but, this is my second purchase of this interesting brew and I like it just as much as the first! Its lively mouthfeel carries this otherwise bitter sweet nectar through the tasting process and the final "let the door slam on your ass" hop kick finishes with finality.

Mine poured with very little head and a malt aroma. Color is orange/red. Malt flavor with a noticable alcohol that isnt at all unpleasant. Semi-bitter citrus aftertaste. This ale has a distinctively stronger taste than most that is quite enjoyable. The English really have a handle on the use of hops that support the beer without overwhelming the malt.

Maple brown cloudy pour with a lasting foamy head. Aroma of malts and dry hop. Taste is very pleasant suprise semi-sweet malt with a fairly strong hop backbone. Hops and carbonation give it a bouyant and light mouthfeel. Read all this as a Brown IPA.

Light brown orange pour with a goodly head. Same distinct Munich yeast aroma that denotes a Marzen. Very smooth malt flavor, not bitter with a light mouthfeel and clean finish. A bit too polished and lacking in character but with excellent flavor. An outstanding seasonal from a large craft brewer.

Beer poured nicley with a smallish head and a malty aroma. Drinking brings out sweet citrus and malt but the mouthfeel falls flat and dry, bordering on skunk. You are left with a bitter, sour aftertaste. Not to my liking.

Medium brown/orange pour. Rich malt and yeast aroma. Sweet malt and yeast flavor are pinned to your tongue with just the right spike of malt. Mouthfeel is a near perfect blend of bitter and carbonation that finishes dryly leaving your mouth aching for another taste. This is a must-try Marzen.

Clear light golden pour with huge head and active effevescence. Quite noticable apple juice aroma which settles into a Belgium style yeast. Immediate sour green apple taste that is quickly brushed away with dry hops. Mouthfeel is very light and dry. Apple sweet is not cloying. All this adds up to a very fun fruit beer that displays excellent depth and skill to craft.

Pours a medium orange brown with an average sized head that receeded quickly. Malt, pumpkin spice and brown sugar aroma. Pumpkin and spice flavor stays largely in the nose, taste is more malt and brown sugar. Good texture and carbonation in mouthfeel. Best Halloween beer Ive tried to date.

Ur-Marzen, just wanted to write that. Nice brown-orange color that raised a finger full of head. Caramelized malt aroma. Malt is nicely braced by the bittering hops and leaves a well blended semi-sweet flavor. Maybe not world-class but an excellent seasonal offering by the local boys here in Portland.

I always feel a sense of relief after opening and pouring a craftbrewers Pale Ale and am rewarded with a nice medium brown gold color instead of a thin yellow fizzy. Jimmy Carter be praised. Sour yeast and malt aroma and a tight smallish head. Yeasty malt flavor is immediately cut by the hops and a steady carbonation works to keep things light and dry. Nice rendition of the style and a surprisingly good offering from Shipyard.
Light ale with some pumpkin spice flavoring. Nothing too inspired and boringly safe.

Poured from a newly released bomber. Reddish amber color with a moderate but tightly bubbled head. Left decent amount of lacing down the sides. Nose is all about the malts. Not the same bite youd expect but drinks more like a brown with aspirations to be red. Excellent mouthfeel that is possibly the best component of this malted voyage. Quick semi-bitter, dry finish.

This is an easy beer to pass over with all the exciting selections to chose from but well worth the sample. Pours a cloudy amber color with an easy two fingers of head. Wonderfully rich yeast and fruity hop aroma. Surprising simple palate with constant carbonation, toffee flavor and quick finish. Not a hint of the 7.5abv at least until the bottom of the glass!

This is a fun beer and one of my seasonal favorites. It pours a medium brown color with a finger of rich frothy head. Sweet malted aroma. Smooth brown sugar and malt taste with subtle hop bracing. Finishes clean with a lingering caramelized malt aftertaste. Grittys seasonal brews are typically better than their flagship brews. They must be more willing to take risks with these and plan the others for the uninitiated masses.

Pours a dark brown with major frothy head. Cinnamon raisin spice aroma. Malted brown sugar and spice flavor with full mouthfeel due to ample carbonation and finishes quick and dry. A beer to be savored.

Clear light golden color that produced a large bubbly head.  Malts and yeast in aroma.  Destinctive lager yeast creates a heavy mouthfeel and simple malt flavor.  Interesting low-key bitter hop finish.
beer_name: Samuel Smiths Pure Brewed Organic Lager

review_blob: Very light clear amber color with ample head and lacing. Floral hop and pine aroma. Mixture of hops combine wonderfully with the malts creating a complex brew with amazingly good bitterness. Taste continues to grow on you as you drink. Zero hint of the 9%abv. I cleaned my local beverage dealer out of Aprihop and it was replaced with 90 Minute. If I clear that out can I get some 120 Minute??!!
Hmm...delicious. Roasted malt and mocha aroma. Sweet tasting dark malts give a huge mouthfeel with a chewy grain and coffee finish. A beer truly worthy of all its praise.

Dark chocolate brown pour with little head, even with some encouraging. Toasted malts with a touch of spice and cocoa to the nose. Pretty tame for a porter and I thought single dimensional until a late coffee, caramel registered. Good honest porter but nothing over the top.

Nice malt aroma with a hint of spice and poured a medium clear brown color. Good malted blend across tongue with a hop zest finish. I managed a single sample but wont hesitate to purchase the twelve-pack to review my findings!

Bought this just across the border from my home state. Light aroma of malts and hops.  Beer was golden colored and clear with smallish head.  Mouthfeel was light and pleasant.  There is nothing exotic about this brew but it is an excellent example of a pale ale and well worth your purchase.

This may be an older sample. Pours a medium brown that provided a good head that quickly diminished and left lacing down the glass. Aroma of malt, spice and yeast. Medium mouthfeel with ample carbonation and nice malty flavor. Subtle yeast and spice finish. Ill be sure to pick up a six of this next seasons Winter Ale, this is one of Cascos best.
beer_name: Casco Bay Winter Ale (Old Port Ale)

review_blob: After having such an incredible beer its difficult to go back and enjoy the mere mortal brewery offerings, but very well understood why so many other brewers like Ommegang, Allagash and the assorted other dubbel makers would try and duplicate. The heady aroma, magnificant maroon color, and distinctive malt, clove and spice flavor are well documented here but needs to be experienced for the special subtleties that make this such a refined and distinctive beer. This is Belgium brewing at its best.
Pours a murky golden color.  Aroma is distinctly Belgium but not strong.  Flavor falls flat as well.  The 7.5abv is very well masked.  Not  a bad beer but too many other good choices to be had.

On draught at Great Lost Bear.  Medium bronze color with an easy two finger frothy head.  Served at room temperature which allowed all flavors to present themselves.  Flavor reminded me of Belgium doubles but with a yeastier more English taste.  Well worth the time to stop in if you are anywhere close to Portland, Maine.
beer_name: Sheepscot Valley Boothbay Special Bitter Pale Ale

review_blob: Pale yellow color with large but quickly receding head. Strong yeast wheat aroma lightly fruity. Very smooth and light to drink but with excellent flavor. Perfect beer to go with Hot Wings!

Had on draught. Medium bronze color with smallish head. Nice malted aroma. Tasted semi-sweet with sweet malts but still light on the tongue. Nice hop backup. Enjoyable beer from a small brewer, probably their best.

Starts life as a triple then is aged in Oak Bourbon barrels. Pours a clear light amber color with a smallish head but active effervescence. Light aroma of crystalized malts and wood. The bourbon soaked oak comes out a bit too strongly in the taste but isnt overwhelming. Excellent mouthfeel and a clean dry finish. No hint of the 11abv in flavor but after drinking the 750ml, Im hammered!

Pours a dark copper color. A good finger and a half of head arose. Lacing traced all the way down the sides. Nice balance of hop and crystal malt in aroma. Hops are less pronounced and bitter to taste than American IPAs but have a fuller body. Finishes very cleanly with a toffee aftertaste. Pour me some more of that swill, Arr!!

Dark bronze pour that raised a large but quickly disappearing head. Malts, brown sugar and spice aroma. Add a touch of cocoa to round out the flavor. This is an outstanding barleywine and feels like a treat to consume.

Black pour with tan head.  Aroma of toasted malt and dark cocoa.  Strong mouthfeel and serious body that elbows its way down.  Good undercurrent of bitter which bounces you up to a quick sweet chocolate hit at top.  Leaves your mouth feeling deliciously used.  This stuff is gonna get hit again and again.

Murky golden color pour that initially produced a large frothy head. Nice floral citrus hop aroma. Malts blend nicely with hops delivering a light but flavorful taste. Finishes with subtle sweet fruit tones with quick hop hit.

If you had told me at the outset of this beer tasting odyssey that Id begin to really enjoy chocolate flavored beers I would of had a witty come back like..."No way!". Hmm. Anywho, this stuff pours as black as a Labrador Retriever and started with a full head but dwindled to just a ring around the edges. I can smell the toasted malts and chocolate aroma with the glass sitting a foot away as I take these notes. Cocoa is evident in the taste but not overpowering and it balances nicely with the stout bitters and malt. Refreshing mouthfeel finishes with a quick hop hit. This is an excellent beer and Im looking forward to this next Maine winter and exploring all the new untried chocolate stouts and porters that Ive gained such an affinity for.

Pours a clear copper color with a large head that dissipated quickly leaving a bubbly lacing. Subtle sweet malted aroma. Fairly light tasting for Bock, decent mouthfeel, bready malt flavor and finishes with a minor hop hit.
Had this on tap.  Clear golden color with small head.  Crisp and light to drink but lacking in flavor.  Just an average summer brew.

Pours a golden honey color and looks murky due to being unfiltered. Strong wheat aroma with banana tones. Not all that pleasant to drink, kinda sour and all that up front aroma seems stale. No crispness. Bitter in finish. Pass on this offering.
